title: 110_s2455
content:
The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title. Additional emergency CDBG funding is addressed in the Act. $1 billion is authorized to be appropriated for assistance to States, metropolitan cities, and urban counties for the community development block grant program to address housing foreclosures and provide foreclosure-based rental assistance. The community development block grant program under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 is allocated $1 billion for housing foreclosure impact, economic and community development activities, and foreclosure-based rental assistance for individual renters. However, funds cannot be used for foreclosure prevention purposes for individual homeowners, except for counseling services. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 allocates $1 billion for housing foreclosure impact, economic and community development activities, and foreclosure-based rental assistance for individual renters. Funds cannot be used for foreclosure prevention purposes for individual homeowners, except for counseling services. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 allocates $1 billion for housing foreclosure impact, economic and community development activities, and foreclosure-based rental assistance for individual renters. Funds cannot be used for foreclosure prevention purposes for individual homeowners, except for counseling services. Financial assistance may be provided directly to certified housing counseling services approved by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 3. INCREASED PUBLIC SERVICES REQUIREMENT CAP.

This Act increases the public services requirement cap from 15% to 25% for all funds appropriated under this Act.

SEC. 4. LOW AND MODERATE INCOME REQUIREMENT.

At least 50% of the funds under this Act must benefit low- and moderate-income individuals.

SEC. 5. PLANS AND REPORTS. (a) Comprehensive Plan.--Funds under this Act cannot be used until a comprehensive plan is submitted and approved by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
(b) Report on Use of Funds.--Recipients must submit quarterly reports detailing the use of funds to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. During the expenditure of funds under this Act, recipients must submit quarterly reports to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development detailing the use of funds. SEC. 6. WAIVERS. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive provisions of statutes or regulations to facilitate the use of funds, except for certain requirements like fair housing and labor standards, upon request by a State, metropolitan city, or urban county. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive certain requirements to facilitate the use of funds, upon request by a State, metropolitan city, or urban county, if it aligns with the overall purpose of the statute. Additionally, a waiver of the 50 percent low and moderate income requirement can be granted if a compelling need is demonstrated. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive requirements upon request by a State, metropolitan city, or urban county if it aligns with the overall purpose of the statute. Waivers for the 50 percent low and moderate income requirement and public service requirement cap may be granted if a compelling need is demonstrated. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may waive the public service requirement cap upon request if a compelling need is demonstrated. Waivers must be published in the Federal Register at least 5 days before taking effect, and each waiver granted will be reviewed. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must publish any waiver of statutes or regulations in the Federal Register at least 5 days before it takes effect. Each waiver granted will be reviewed and reconsidered by the Secretary within 2 years of its initial publication. Each waiver granted by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must be reconsidered and reauthorized within 2 years of its initial publication in the Federal Register. The Secretary must also notify the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations of any waivers granted or denied within 5 days. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must notify the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations of any waiver granted or denied within 5 days. SEC. 7 of the Act addresses noncompliance with community development requirements, referencing section 111 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. SEC. 8 mandates a GAO audit. SEC. 8 of the Act requires the Comptroller General to conduct an audit of all funds appropriated under the Act and submit a report to the relevant committees. SEC. 9. REPORTS. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must report quarterly to the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations regarding the use of funds under this Act, including the number of households receiving counseling and rental assistance, outcomes of assistance activities, names of certified housing counseling services, and any other relevant information. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must report quarterly to Congress on the use of funds, including the number of households receiving counseling and rental assistance, outcomes of assistance activities, names of certified housing counseling services, and steps taken to prevent fraud and abuse of funds.
